data.title: St. Pat's timeline - 105 years
data.text: 1 Start DateEnd DateHeadlineTextMediaMedia CreditMedia CaptionMedia ThumbnailTypeTag 2 3/1/1908The tradition beginsA student request for a day off to celebrate St. Patrick’s Day was denied but the students decided to skip classes anyway. They marched to Norwood Hall where, draped in a green robe, one of the students, George Menefee, portrayed St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/ourfirst1.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1908_t.jpgtitle 3 3/1/1909Showing respectStudents kowtow to W.M. Holmes, the 1909 St. Pat, in front of Norwood Hall as a gesture of deep respect. This year also marked the beginning of many of the characteristics featured in modern celebrations, including the parade.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19091.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1909_t.jpg 4 3/1/1910First Shillelagh DayDavid L. “Red” Forrester, the 1910 St. Pat, bestows a blessing. He rode on a water wagon drawn by six big mules at the head of the parade. According to the Missouri Miner, this year also marks the first Shillelagh Day, when freshmen were sent into the woods to cut the necessary arms for the occasion.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19101.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1910_t.jpg 5 3/1/1911St. Pat's marks another firstThe 1911 St. Pat, W.A. Hackwood, had the honor of knighting Eva Endurance Hirdler, the first female mining engineer to graduate from MSM.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19111.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1911_t.jpg 6 3/1/1912A parade with rich historyHarry Nowlan, the 1912 St. Pat, rides in his chariot through downtown Rolla. This marks the first year in which there was an evening program. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19121.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1912_t.jpg 7 3/1/1913A masquerade ballMore than 100 people were in disguise at the grand march to the Masquerade Dance, led by Arthur Truex, 1913 St. Pat. According to the Rollamo, refreshments were provided and many present had the pleasure, for the first time, of “putting a foot on the rail and calling for such fancy drinks as a ‘Mechanic’s Swizzle,’ ‘Doc Louey’s Best,’ and ‘Bronze and Cast Iron’ cocktails. What matter if all orders were filled in lemonade and cider, the devilishness of it made up for lack of strength.”https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19131.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1913_t.jpg 8 3/1/1914Rain, rain, go awayFrank L. Johnson, the 1914 St. Pat, officiated the knighting ceremonies. Reports say the day was somewhat spoiled by a heavy downpour of rain, but because the spirit of the celebration had such a firm root, the ceremonies were carried out as usual.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19141.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1914_t.jpg 9 3/1/1915Long live the queenAccording to the Rollamo, St. Patrick’s Day was clear and cool. By 9 a.m., a monster parade was organized and ready to receive John J. Doyle as St. Patrick. A long procession of floats, and individual stunts, led by Doyle himself, passed through the main streets and then to Norwood Hall. Helen Baysinger, the daughter of a local physician who was active in politics, was crowned the first Queen of Love and Beauty.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19151.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1915_t.jpg 10 3/1/1916A ‘Red Letter Day’The weather for this St. Pat’s Day was “made to order,” according to the Rollamo. Between 25 and 30 floats participated in the parade at 8:30 a.m., including the Grubstakers’ replica of a camp. The new gymnasium “furnished an ideal place for the Masque Ball,” according to the Missouri Miner. John H.G. Reilly was St. Pat this year, and Mary McCrae was crowned his queen.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19161.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1916_t.jpg 11 3/1/1917A cold, blustery dayCicardi's orchestra provided music at the Masquerade Ball, where H. Smith Clark portrayed St. Pat and crowned Olive Scott queen. According to the Rollamo, chords of "Home, Sweet Home" floated through Jackling Gymnasium until 4 a.m.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1917.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1917_t.jpg 12 3/1/1918St. Pat BlarneyAfter the parade, Meryl McCarthy, the 1918 St. Pat, called each senior to come forward. According to the Rollamo, seniors had to answer embrassing questions, kneel and kiss the blarney stone in order to receive a diploma. This year Mrs. Frederick D. Gardner, then the first lady of the state, reigned as queen.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19181.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1918_t.jpg 13 3/1/1919And the crowds cameMore than 2,000 people reportedly lined the streets of Rolla to see Edwin K. Schumann, the 1919 St. Pat, lead the parade. That evening, approximatley 200 couples participated in the grand march following the coronation ceremony, according to the Rollamo.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19191.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1919_t.jpg 14 3/1/1920St. Pat’s ConventionEleven engineering schools, including MSM, sent representatives to a convention held in Columbia, Mo., focused on making St. Pat’s celebrations a national custom in engineering schools. Three MSM students attended the convention, where a national pin was designed to be worn “by all duly dubbed ‘knights,’ ‘honrary knights’ and ‘ladies,’ according to the Rollamo. This year, Albert B. Needham served as St. Pat and Edna Kiel, daughter of the St. Louis mayor, served as queen.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19201.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1920_t.jpg 15 3/1/1921A Jewell of a saintJames E. Jewell, St. Pat of 1922, watched over the “stunts” during this authorized holiday, according to the Rollamo. Activities included a parade, a minstrel show, the Masquerade Ball and the knighting ceremonies. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19211.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1921_t.jpg 16 3/1/1922One enchanted eveningThe Follies had reportedly been on the decline since its introduction in 1916, according to the Missouri Miner. This year the MSM Players took the stage for the presentation of some of their amateur dramatic act. That evening, the Quadrangle Orchestra from Columbia furnished music for the dance, which was attended by 425 couples. Margaret Sally was crowned queen by St. Pat David F. Walsh.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19221.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1922_t.jpg 17 3/1/1923Lucky charmersCurtis Stover, the 1923 St. Pat, crowned his wife, Helen Stover, queen. The royal pair reviewed the Grand March from a castle that had been erected in one corner.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1923.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1923_t.jpg 18 3/1/1924It’s electricA feature of the dance’s decorations this year were electric light signs. According to the Rollamo, “the intermittent flashes from these signs created a beautiful effect when the other lights in the hall were dim.”https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1924.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1924_t.jpg 19 3/1/1925Can’t rain on the paradeIn 1925, the celebration took the form of those of preceeding years with one notable exception: the usual parade, with its many floats, was eliminated that year. Helen Berniece Underwood was crowned queen by Ray Kollar as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19251.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1925_t.jpg 20 3/1/1926It’s time to masqueradeThe gym was transformed for the masquerade ball. The cold, rainy evening was forgotten as Dorothy Keiser was crowned the Queen of Love and Beauty for the 1926 St. Pat’s celebration by St. Pat Ralph G. Hilpert.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19261.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1926_t.jpg 21 3/1/1927Sisters, sistersFor the first time in the history of St. Pat’s festivities, a former Queen’s sister sat on the throne. Lorraine Love was crowned queen by Gerald A. Roberts. Her older sister, Nancy Love, reigned in 1920.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19271.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1927_t.jpg 22 3/1/1928I love LucyIn 1928, St. Pat arrived in a blinding snowstorm, according to the Missouri Miner. At midnight during Friday evening’s masquerade ball, B.L. Ballard as St. Pat arrived to crown Lucy Kiesler as his queen. Students danced to the music of Irving from St. Louis.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19281.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1928_t.jpg 23 3/1/1929A big splashDespite heavy downpours, this year’s festivities continued. Odell’s College Club Orchestra of St. Louis played “The Wearing of the Green” as St. Pat James K. Richards approached his throne. Elizabeth Long, with escorts and maids in tow, was crowed queen.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1929.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1929_t.jpg 24 3/1/1930Party queensAt midnight, the heralds announced the approach of St. Pat to the Masquerade Ball. Silence reportedly fell over the crowd as former queens entered Jackling Gym, part of a procession needed to crown Madge Lennox the 16th queen of St. Pat. A.J. Tiefenbrun as St. Pat stepped forth to welcome her to the throne, according to the Rollamo.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19301.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1930_t.jpg 25 3/1/1931St. Pat’s Board createdAccording to the Alumnus magazine, in 1931 it was decided that the “time-honored St. Pat celebration” would no longer be a responsibility of the junior class alone. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19311.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1931_t.jpg 26 3/1/1932A gym transformedFor the Grand Masquerade Ball, the walls of Jackling Gym were covered in red velour, overlayed with “glistening” silver. James Parker as St. Pat crowned Emily McCaw the Queen of Love and Beauty, to reign with him over the 1932 celebration.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19321.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1932_t.jpg 27 3/1/1933The sounds of St. Pat'sKMOX radio station in St. Louis broadcasts two 15-minute segements of the music from the masquerade ball, according to the MSM Alumnus.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19331.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1933_t.jpg 28 3/1/1934The craziest man in school'According to the Rollamo, John C. Settle suited the position of St. Pat “like tomato juice suits him every Sunday morning.” Known to friends as “Soapy,” Settle is described as being “known to his many friends as the craziest man in school since he first flunked chemistry. And that is quite some time ago as he is now flunking for the fifth or sixth time, we lost count.”https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19341.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1934_t.jpg 29 3/1/1935The roaring 20thFrederick W. Arnold and Dorothy Fort reigned over the 20th St. Pat’s celebration.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19351.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1935_t.jpg 30 3/1/1936No lions or bears, just elephantsAt about 9:30 a.m. Friday morning, Walter L. Holz as St. Pat made his dramatic entrance at the Frisco Depot on his handcar, escorted by his pages and guards. He was led through town with an escort of elephants, horses, old cars and many cheering students, according to the MSM Alumnus report.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19361.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1936_t.jpg 31 3/1/1937Let the revelry beginThe Independents officially opened the 29th annual St. Pat’s celebration, whose dance in Jackling Gym featured music of Chan Chandler. Roger C. Tittel, as St. Pat, transferred the crown from Jean Campbell, the 1936 queen, to Mildren Brown.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19371.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1937_t.jpg 32 3/1/1938A lot of blarneyJohn R. Post as St. Pat watches carefully as a student kisses the official Blarney Stone. According to the Rollamo, “St. Pat had an idea that he could bring in a ‘ringer’ but the fear of probation caused him to produce this object. It served the purpose, however, very well.”https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19381.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1938_t.jpg 33 3/1/1939Roman the streetsSamuel A. Kurtz as St. Pat arrvies at the Frisco depot, assisted by his guards and pages before leading the parade through the main streets of Rolla. Friday night Kurtz crowned Mary McCrae his queen. An S&T student, McCrae was the first daughter of a Rolla graduate ever to be named queen.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19391.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1939_t.jpg 34 3/1/1940From the highways to the railwayRobert S. Dorsey as St. Pat arrives via handcar. Dorsey worked for the Missouri Highway Department for two years before enrolling at MSM. Friday’s evening festivities were announced by KMOX news director Harry Flannery. The program included 15 minutes of dance music by Bob Zurke and his orchestra prior to the coronation, a description of the coronation, and 15 minutes of dance music to close the broadcast. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19401.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1940_t.jpg 35 3/1/1941Love and beauty on displayJazz trumpeter Henry Busse entertained the audience at Friday night’s Costume Ball, where John H. Lyons as St. Pat crowned Lucille Stimson as Queen of Love and Beauty.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19411.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1941_t.jpg 36 3/1/1942Written proof!A Missouri Miner newspaper article recounts a tale of how a thesis conclusively proved that St. Pat was the first engineer. This year John A. Mazzoni served as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19421.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1942_t.jpg 37 3/1/1943St. Pat in St. Nick's court?Raymond O. Kasten as St. Pat made an early appearance this year, visiting in December at the Winter Carnival. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19431.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1943_t.jpg 38 3/1/1944Wartime interruptionsAll able-bodied men had been drafted and were fighting in World War II. According to one account, “there was no waiting until the end of the semester. Often they would be notified in the middle of the week and told to report in one or two days to Kansas City, St. Louis, Springfield, etc.” 39 3/1/1945The Best Ever in the worst conditionsWith just 203 students enrolled in MSM in the fall of 1944, St. Pat’s activities remained non-existent on the campus. But even in war time, Rolla alumni found a way to celebrate the Best Ever. While in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp, Robert Silhavy, CerE’41, and Gene Boyt, ME’41, found a way to improvise their version of the Best Ever. Read about it. 40 3/1/1946A triumphant returnThe St. Pat’s celebration resumed at Rolla. As was tradition, Robert T. White as St. Pat arrived in Rolla at the Frisco Depot by handcar. That evening, he greeted his 1946 Queen of Love and Beauty Lenore Jones, a student at Lindenwood College.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19461.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1946_t.jpg 41 3/1/1947St. Pat's on paradeEarly Friday afternoon, Harold C. Brehe as St. Pat arrived on his handcar. He led the parade of floats entered by various fraternities and organizations through the streets of Rolla, ending at Parker Hall.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19471.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1947_t.jpg 42 3/1/1948It's good to be queenSue Gleason was crowned Queen of Love and Beauty by James B. McGrath as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19481.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1948_t.jpg 43 3/1/1949Rah-Rah RollaAn undignified fertilizer spreader provides transportation for St. Pat, portrayed by Don E. Spackler, who frequently ordered his freshmen to halt in front of stores for refreshments.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19491.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1949_t.jpg 44 3/1/1950New wheels for the old hibernianRobert E. Schuchardt as St. Pat rides in a “spanking new” chariot, according to the MSM Alumnus. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19501.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1950_t.jpg 45 3/1/1951A snowy, muddy celebrationAmidst snow and mud, Joseph H. Geers as St. Pat made his entry into Rolla for the annual celebration on his behalf. At that evening’s Costume Ball, Alice Walthall was crowed the Queen of Love and Beauty.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19511.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1951_t.jpg 46 3/1/1952The classic arrivalDick Hampel as St. Pat arrives in Rolla for the 1952 St. Pat celebration.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19521.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1952_t.jpg 47 3/1/1953That's what it's all about'The Ray Anthony Orchestra provided mellow notes for the evening’s activities, where Joan Christian (left) was selected to reign as Queen of Love and Beauty with James A. Gerard as St. Pat. Anthony (right) was known for classic dance songs like “The Bunny Hop” and the “Hokey Pokey.”https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19531.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1953_t.jpg 48 3/1/1954There once was a fellow named Smith ...'Frederick J. Smith portrayed St. Pat this year, addressing his loyal followers and conferring the honor of knighthood upon his faithful senior subjects. Smith crowned June Lange his Queen of Love and Beauty.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19541.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1954_t.jpg 49 3/1/1955Murphy's law ruled '55St. Pat, portrayed by James M. Murphy, crowned Shirley Marie Brueggeman as the Queen of Love and Beauty. The Costume Ball followed to the strains of “Music in the Morgan Manner.”https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19551.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1955_t.jpg 50 3/1/1956Speech! Speech!Donald R. McGovern as St. Pat delivers the annual knighting ceremony speech.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19561.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1956_t.jpg 51 3/1/1957Goodnight, MarilynThe 1957 St. Pat’s Celebration closed Saturday evening at Jackling Gym as Warren J. Carrol, portraying St. Pat, crowned Marilyn Goodnight as Queen of Love and Beauty.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19571.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1957_t.jpg 52 3/1/1958Parade libationsDave McClure (center) and Don Modesitt (right) enjoy the parade, led by Ronald B. Huseman as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19581.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1958_t.jpg 53 3/1/1959A lucky Friday the 13thGrover Murphy portrayed St. Pat and arrived in Rolla on Friday the 13th, marking a lucky day for all Miners. Murphy is pictured with Linda Fitzgerald, the Queen of Love and Beauty, and the rest of the court.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1959.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1959_t.jpg 54 3/1/1960Winning beardsDon J. Gunther as St. Pat awards beard contest mugs.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19601.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1960_t.jpg 55 3/1/1961They’re having a ballJimmy Cook and his Orchestra, recently honored as the “Best College Band of the Year,” provided music for the St. Pat’s Ball, where Harvey G. Martin as St. Pat and Sharon Anstedt as Queen of Love and Beauty reigned.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19611.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1961_t.jpg 56 3/1/1962Getting their kicksBeta Sigma Psi's parade float took top honors.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1962.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1962_t.jpg 57 3/1/1963Charles in chargeFrom beard contests to the potent knighting ceremony, Miners celebrated St. Pat’s with a variety of activities -- all carried out under the watchful eye of Charles P. Becker as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19631.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1963_t.jpg 58 3/1/1964St. Pat’s royaltyKeith E. Bailey, from Lambda Chi Alpha, reigned as St. Pat of 1964. His Queen of Love and Beauty was Mrs. Vickie Harwell.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19641.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1964_t.jpg 59 3/1/1965Follow the green-lined streetLes Blumberg, Judy Cox and Russ Cotys apply the green line to Pine Street. This year Clyde A. Vandivort portrayed St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19651.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1965_t.jpg 60 3/1/1966Knight, meet AliceAnother worthy subject is officially knighted by St. Patrick’s guards. This year’s St. Pat was John “Harb” Henry.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19661.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1966_t.jpg 61 3/1/1967Another student knight meets AliceThe knighting ceremony is enough to turn a man green. William C. Castle portrayed St. Pat this year.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19671.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1967_t.jpg 62 3/1/1968Bestowing St. Pat’s honorsCharles J. Fehlig as St. Pat prepared to dub several Missouri dignitaries honorary knights of his court, including UMR Chancellor Merl Baker, U.S. Rep. Richard Ichord, State Sen. J.F. Patterson, Rolla Mayor Eugene Northern and John A. Tryon.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19681.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1968_t.jpg 63 3/1/1969Pick a winnerBright-eyed St. Pat, portrayed by Kappa Sig’s John J. Moll, judges the finals of a contest at the Lion’s Park pavilion.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19691.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1969_t.jpg 64 3/1/1970Bring on the knightsA large crowd waits for the knights to meet Alice. Eric D. Dunning potrayed St. Pat this year.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19701.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1970_t.jpg 65 3/1/1971St. Pat memorializedKenny C. Hilterbrand potrayed St. Pat this year. On Friday, Oct. 23, the St. Pat’s Board presented the university with a statue of St. Patrick. https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19711.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1971_t.jpg 66 3/1/1972State leaders honoredPortrayed by Daniel F. Mullen, St. Pat made four honorary knights including James C. Kirkpatrick, Missouri secretary of state. Nancy Benesh was named the 1972 Queen of Love and Beauty and the Coronation Ball. Miss Missouri was also in attendance for many of the activities.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19721.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1972_t.jpg 67 3/1/1973Men of honorRoger L. Kramer as St. Pat gave Missouri Sen. Thomas F. Eagleton (second from right) the honor of honrary St. Pat. His was the second in the history of the St. Pat celebration. Three others received the accolade of Honorary Knight of St. Pat, including (from left) MSM-UMR Alumni Association president Peter F. Mattei, Jerome T. Berry and J. Stuart Johnson.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19731.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1973_t.jpg 68 3/1/1974And the green goes onAlumni board reps paint Pine Street green in preparation for the parade, led by Roger L. Van Deven as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19741.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1974_t.jpg 69 3/1/1975Real men of St. Pat’sThe Budweiser Clydesdales made their appearance at the parade, which was led by Bernard H. Scheer III as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19751.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1975_t.jpg 70 3/1/1976Red, white and blue ... and greenGerald L. Meyr portrayed St. Pat this year.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19761.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1976_t.jpg 71 3/1/1977Float onFloats filled the parade, which was led by James E. Grelle as St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19771.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1977_t.jpg 72 3/1/1978That’s a lot of beersRussell L. Goldammer potrayed St. Pat for the 70th annual celebration.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19781.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1978_t.jpg 73 3/1/1979Some knightsGary L. Underwood as St. Pat and James Kirkpatrick knight UMR Chancellor Joseph Marcello.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19791.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1979_t.jpg 74 3/1/1980Walk onBrian L. Wagner as St. Pat awards the winners of the walking stick contest.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19801.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1980_t.jpg 75 3/1/1981I love a paradeWayne V. Schmidt as St. Pat received a warm welcome to the parade.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19811.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1981_t.jpg 76 3/1/1982A date with AliceEach year student knights are elected from fraternities and select organizations for their worthiness. Their reward? A date with the renowned Alice. This year Michael A. Avery portrayed St. Pat.https://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/19821.jpgArchiveshttps://bestever.mst.edu/files/2013/02/1982_t.jpg 77 3/1/1983Who’s got the button?William R.
